headline.print_headline: Bill Strikes at Low-Nutrition Foods in School
headline.main: Bill Strikes at Low-Nutrition Foods in School

docs.lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group in Congress plans to introduce legislation that would prohibit the sale in school of fatty or sugary foods, including soft drinks.
docs.snippet: A bipartisan group in Congress plans to introduce legislation that would prohibit the sale in school of fatty or sugary foods, including soft drinks.

headline.main: Child Obesity Picture Grim Among New York City Poor

docs.abstract: New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene finds that many city preschool children from low-income families are likely to be obese; study puts city well above national average in terms of child obesity prevalence; data for study come from most recent records of 16,000 children involved in Head Start program (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A baby only 3 months old can recognize voices. By the age of 1, that baby can learn to walk and talk and enjoy looking at picture books. Then, by the age of 2, there is a one-in-four chance that the child will be obese -- at least if he or she lives in New York City and is from a low-income family, according to a survey of preschool children released yesterday by the City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.
docs.snippet: A baby only 3 months old can recognize voices. By the age of 1, that baby can learn to walk and talk and enjoy looking at picture books.     Then, by the age of 2, there is a one-in-four chance that the child will be obese -- at least if he or she...

headline.print_headline: Low-Calorie Diet May Lead To Longer Life, Study Finds
headline.main: Low-Calorie Diet May Lead to Longer Life

docs.lead_paragraph: A study lends support to the theory that eating less may benefit even the non-obese.
docs.snippet: A study lends support to the theory that eating less may benefit even the non-obese.

docs.abstract: Article on growing number suburban planners and developers who, faced with growing concerns about social isolation, roadside dangers and lethargy, are placing new emphasis on sidewalks; push for walkable communities has won support in public health circles but critics say some recent efforts to get suburbanites on their feet are misguided; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: FOR Jennifer Girsdansky, life in the outer reaches of suburbia has its charms. Her family's 26 acres allow her 2-year-old daughter, Sophia, plenty of room to roam and her 10-year-old son, Brandon, the chance to go sledding without leaving the property. But this car-dependent community, where parents turn into chauffeurs and neighbors cruise past one another at 40 miles an hour, can present challenges as well. Ms. Girsdansky, a 41-year-old single mother, says the neighborhood can feel a bit lonely. Lately it has even felt dangerous.
docs.snippet: Faced with growing concerns about the byproducts of a car-centric culture, planners and developers in the subdivision suburbs are placing a new emphasis on sidewalks.

docs.abstract: William L Hamilton article on his sleeplessness and his experience at sleep clinic to determine cause; he is diagnosed with mild case of sleep apnea, one of the more than 80 identifiable sleep disorders that include restless leg syndrome and insomnia; Dr William C Dement, director of Sleep Disorders Clinic and Research Center at Stanford University, says 90 percent of our waking health is dependent on our sleep; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: TRY this sometime. Plaster about two dozen electrodes to your face and head and tape some more to your chest and legs. Give yourself two to three feet of wire on each, and attach the other ends to the wall next to a bed, so they tug tightly when you move. Make sure the bed is in a room that you've never seen before, something that looks like a hospital room disguised as a hotel room. A kind of Soviet-era bugged spy box for information gathering, with a video camera, pointed at the bed, blinking silently from the ceiling.
docs.snippet: Sleep has become a commercial industry. In addition to pills, breathing masks and specialty bedding, there are sleep clinics, which are proliferating.

headline.main: $6 Million Gift Resurrects Boot Camp for Diabetics

docs.abstract: Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan will be able to reopen diabetes center because of $6 million donation from Gerald J and Dorothy R Friedman New York Foundation for Medical Research; center will provide variety of care; hospital will use part of donation to finance diabetes research (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan opened a center focused solely on treating diabetics in 1999, the idea was simple: provide much of the care a diabetic needs under one roof -- focusing on nutrition and education and controlling blood sugar levels -- and the serious complications wrought by the disease could be avoided. But the effort failed.
